reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: I’ve made my living sticking to businesses I understand—consumer products, insurance, banking, railroads. Carmaking, especially high-tech EVs, sits outside my circle. I’d be venturing into unfamiliar territory. 2. Competitive Moat: Tesla has a strong brand, but the auto business is capital-intensive and fiercely competitive. Brand alone won’t keep 20 competitors from cutting prices or matching tech. 3. Management Quality: Elon Musk is a visionary, but his attention is spread across too many ventures. I prefer managers who behave like owners, take the long view, and don’t chase headlines. 4. Financial Health: With no reliable data here and knowing the auto industry’s boom-and-bust cycle, I’d worry about inconsistent earnings and heavy debt in downturns. 5. Valuation: Without intrinsic value calculations or a margin of safety, I have no confidence the market price is reasonable. “Price is what you pay; value is what you get.” 6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: EVs will be part of tomorrow’s world, but battery, regulatory, and competitive risks run high. I’m wary when complexity is the story. 7. Compared to My Portfolio: I’d much rather own Coca-Cola with its decades-old brand and steady cash, or Apple as a consumer ecosystem play. Tesla simply doesn’t fit my criteria. In short, I’d pass.
